Unnamed: 1: We have used the FY22 - 24 targets to inform our refreshed ESG Strategy, the development of our Social IQ tool and our commitment to create over $1.0bn1 in social value by 2030. Our approach to Social Impact commencing in FY24 will be focused, purposeful investment in universal and place-based needs integrated into our business and scaled through our CARE Foundation. For more information on our approach please refer to our Social Management Approach and ESG Strategy in our Annual Report.

During FY23 we continued to deliver on the comitments whilst refreshing our ESG Strategy. Our progress is detailed below. Changes to targets have been indicated throughout. We believe our refreshed approach will deliver more impactful change for local communities.

Unnamed: 3: Undertake accessibility assessments for all Town Centres and benchmark the level of compliance and customer amenity (including dignity, equity and inclusion).

Unnamed: 6: Accessibility Assessments continued in FY23 at Rockhampton, Birtinya, Hervey Bay and Townsville. Recommendations are presented to the asset teams for actioning. To date, thirteen centres have completed assessments. This target will change to align with refreshed ESG Strategy.

Unnamed: 3: Develop a shopping experience rating/benchmark for people shopping with disabilities.

Unnamed: 3: Deliver a minimum of one Liveable Housing Australia (LHA) certified home (Silver Standard) in each display village with fewer than 20 lots, and two homes in display villages with more than 20 lots applicable where individual builders are allocate 3 lots or more

Unnamed: 3: Minimum of one education program per community (school delivery or direct community program).
Unnamed: 4: Delivered the Big Battery challenge to 24 schools nationally with our partner The National Theatre for Children. This engaged 15,544 students and 824 teachers, helping them understand the benefits of recycling. By the end of the 2021 school year, the program had collectively diverted 2,005 kilograms of batteries from landfill and abated 7,241kgs of CO2e.
Unnamed: 6: Delivered the Big Battery challenge to 25 schools nationally with our partner The National Theatre for Children. This engaged 19,202 students and 857 teachers, helping them understand the benefits of recycling. In total over FY23, 7048kg of batteries were recycled, 306,434 AA batteries were diverted from landfill and 28,804kg of CO2e avoided. This target will change to align with refreshed ESG Strategy and approach to Social Impact.

Unnamed: 3: Partner with community organisations including the Australian Retailers Association (ARA) through their Retail Ready Program to facilitate the placement of 100 long-term unemployed Australians (local residents / community members unemployed for more than six months).
Unnamed: 4: We have continued working with the ARA through their Retail Ready Program to facilitate the placement of unemployed people into vacant jobs. In FY22, the ARA were able to provide 93 jobseekers with the opportunity to pursue vacancies in StocklandÃ¢ÂÂs Town Centres, which fell just short of our target. This process was hindered by the impacts of COVID-related lockdowns and other restrictions, which led to fewer job openings across the Retail sector.
Unnamed: 6: During FY23 we focused on preventative solutions through partnering to deliver taylored, place-based employability focused programs that meet local need. Examples include Mounty Yarns with Justice Reinvest, Youngster and ABCN programs that target youth at risk. We will revisit our partnership with ARA as part of our Universal Needs initiative. This target will change to align with refreshed ESG Strategy and approach to Social Impact.

Unnamed: 1: Build resilience for our people and places to help them adapt to a changing world.
